titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the essay on historic Brooklyn highways 1973.176
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:11:24 +0000.

did.abstract: One handwritten essay describing the development and function of highways in Brooklyn from the time of the Dutch settlements to the early 1800s. The essay is written in a roll book of the Berkley Lawn Tennis Club, with the first several pages torn out. A small amount of loose notes, written on the back of Tennis Club fliers, are filed throughout. The author of the essay is unknown, but the volume contains the inscription "W.S.G., 837 Monroe Street, Brooklyn, L.I." on the inside cover.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Essay on historic Brooklyn highways, 1973.176, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Dewitt C. Drury, date unknown. The collection was formally accessioned in 1973.
